history.content:
I took CS61C and CS170 Sophomore fall as well. It was a good amount of work but I still had a lot of time (~10-15 hours) for extracurriculars.

I think you could probably do Physics 7B/CS188 and be able to handle everything (assuming you're not doing much else). I do not recommend doing 127/126 with your current schedule.

If you felt familiar with the Linear from EE16A/B and are decently comfortable with more rigorous mathematical proofs, 110 shouldn't be bad as a third technical. The class is mostly just a conceptual recap of the linear you should've picked up from 16A/B, with a couple of extra topics thrown in there. If you don't mind proof-based thinking and/or did fine in 70, I think it'd be easy to fit 110 into your schedule. This semester Frenkel is teaching and the homeworks aren't even collected so it's super chill, but that part will obviously depend on the professor.

I took CS61C and CS170 Sophomore fall as well. It was a good amount of work but I still had a lot of time (~10-15 hours) for extracurriculars.

I think you could probably do Physics 7B/CS188 and be able to handle everything (assuming you're not doing much else). I do not recommend doing 127/126 with your current schedule.

children.subject: I’m in 7B right now and the work load is not that heavy. You only have weekly hw that’s ~10 questions due every Friday (I have Zettl so the format of the class might vary for diff profs). Depending on how familiar you are with physics the most challenging part of the class will be understanding the concepts since the actual assignment aren’t that heavy. That being said, the exams are usually pretty different from the homework and the averages for the midterm we just had was around 63% so you would most likely find yourself putting more time into studying than the actual assignment part of the class. Overall, the difficulty of this class comes from exams and concepts (however I didn’t take AP physics in high school so I’m also just less familiar with the content, other people in the class who have some exposure to the topics are not having as hard a time learning the material), while the workload is pretty light. For Zettl, your grade is broken down into HW, 5 quizzes, exams, and labs. As long as you do well in hw/quizzes/labs (which are all easy to get 90%+ in), and study for the tests the class should be fine for you

history.content:
Hello, going to be a sophomore EECS major and was wondering what classes to take along with CS61C and CS170. I understand that these are going to take up a lot of time, but I want to do a third technical that hopefully won't be too bad. I have taken CS61A, B and EE16A B as well as CS 70 and Math 53. I am debating between:

Math 110

Physics 7B

EE126

EE127

CS188
history.subject: CS61C + CS170 + ?
